--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...> wrote:
>=
 If there is very bad rust pitting, it's possible that you will be
left wit=
h substantial holes after removing the rust. 

Hi, trying to get caught up,=
 and probably violating the five minute
rule.  Be that as it may, let me in=
terject two self-learned Chicken
truths about rust:

1. It's always worse t=
han it looks.  If there is ANY surface
discoloration (red, black, gray, eve=
n white), then there is pitting. 
More a problem, of course, on blades as o=
pposed to tsuba.  But any
rusting of any kind means more than just finger s=
tones on blades to
correct the damage.  I have not the experience on kodogu=
 to say
something even semi-intelligent, but suspect that if any discolorat=
ion
is removed, the surface will not be as smooth as when first made,
unles=
s considerable nearby unrusted metal is removed as well.

2. When there is =
scabby red/brown rust on blades, the pitting is kinda
bad to extremely bad,=
 and it's difficult to impossible to tell simply
by looking which it is.  T=
his Chicken truism comes from polishing
("Forgive me, God, for I have sinne=
d") two Pacific Era gunto with
equivalent scabby surface rust.  Paradoxical=
ly, on the the traditional
tamahagane (no stamps) gunto, the rust pits went=
 to China, in depth
they were as long or longer than their width.  I couldn=
't get out all
the pitting without grinding away over three hundred years w=
orth of
metal, and had ot give up with about five percent of the pits
remai=
ning.  On the non-traditional, Seki-stamped gunto (Kumemune
mentioned a whi=
le ago), though the surface rust was essentially
identical, the pits were n=
o where near as deep, and, as it turned out,
not deeper than the waves in t=
he crap wartime polish, and so were not
the major concern in the end.

Bott=
om line, rust is either bad, or extremely bad, and it's tough to
tell betwe=
en the two before getting serious.  FWIW, JMO.

NC  ;o)
